Lincoln Ave. (2600N, 700W) Chicago, IL 60614 (773) 348-1666, 34382=Prior to its days as Kelsey's, the place once served as "Der Red Barron" and was run by Herbert Schmid dating back to 1970. "There's no entertainment, but the ceiling of varnished magazine covers gives you plenty to stare at. There's a friendly tip over the bar: 'Save Lincoln Avenue wildlife, tip the bartender," according to Cheryl Lavin in her Chicago Tribune article, "Walking Tour of Eats and Arts and Shops and All that Jazz," (June 23, 1978).}
textBeforeTable: "A Classic Old Style Neighborhood Saloon" Kelsey's 2265 N. Lincoln Ave. (2600N, 700W) Chicago, IL 60614 (773) 348-1666   Written by Sean Parnell   © The Chicago Bar Project
textAfterTable: Like a combination of Sterch's down the block and Kendall's next door, Kelsey's appeals to the Lincoln Park hordes with sports on the televisions, Golden Tee, pool, a classic Chicago neighborhood bar environ, and one of the most impressive bar-backs in the city. Too bad it's not bigger or maybe it could even give John Barleycorn's Memorial Pub a run for its money. Whatever the case, Kelsey's is a good place for North Side craic. Just don't get it confused with Kendall's or Kincade's (under the same ownership), Kelly's Pub, Kasey's, or any other bar beginning with "K." "On the weekends the fratitude is out of control, meaning you can expect to be crammed face to armpit with hygiene deficient meatheads, much hollering back and forth over the noise, and an aneurysm trying to get a drink."  Shecky's Bar, Club & Lounge Guide 2002 To find Kelsey's, just look for the 50's diner-like neon signs  one that hangs out over the street and one that hangs above the door, just under the tiny multi-colored awning.
